question: [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Information disclosure] Does the error message at line 148 that includes {:#} formatting disclose sensitive information about the node's internal state, network topology, or system configuration that aids targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Error message injection] Can an attacker craft system information values that include format string specifiers or injection payloads that get embedded in the explanation field (lines 94, 110, 120), potentially exploiting downstream log processing? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: get_system_information_value()] [Missing key disclosure] Does the error message \

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Value disclosure] Do the detailed explanations at lines 110 and 120 that include actual hardware values disclose node capacity information useful for planning resource exhaustion attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Parse error details] Does the error message at line 94 that includes the parse error details leak information about the expected format that helps attackers craft bypass payloads? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Off-by-one] The comparison at line 105 uses value_from_target < minimum, but should it be <= to prevent edge cases where value equals minimum from passing when they shouldn't? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Boundary condition] If value_from_target equals minimum exactly (e.g., exactly 8 cores), does the >= comparison logic at line 105 correctly classify this as passing when the minimum might be exclusive rather than inclusive? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [Zero value] If minimum is set to 0 (through configuration), does the comparison at line 105 become meaningless, always returning score=100 and completely bypassing hardware validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check_single_item()] [MAX value] If value_from_target is u64::MAX, can this cause issues in the comparison at line 105 or in the format strings at lines 110 and 120 when converting to display? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Concurrent modification] Between checking CPU (line 154) and RAM (line 160), can the system information change due to race conditions, causing inconsistent validation results? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Struct: HardwareCheckerConfig] [Required flag bypass] Can an attacker manipulate the common.required field (inherited from CommonCheckerConfig) to make this checker non-required, allowing nodes with inadequate hardware to skip validation entirely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: new()] [Constructor bypass] Does the new() constructor at line 56 perform any validation of the config parameter, or can an attacker pass a maliciously crafted config with internally inconsistent values? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Struct: HardwareCheckerConfig] [Serde default bypass] Can an attacker exploit the #[serde(default)] attributes to omit min_cpu_cores and min_ram_gb from the configuration, causing the checker to use default values even when stricter requirements were intended? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Struct: HardwareCheckerConfig] [Default override] Can an attacker override the default_min_cpu_cores() and default_min_ram_gb() functions through trait implementation or other Rust mechanisms to weaken hardware requirements? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Struct: HardwareCheckerConfig] [Flatten attribute] Does the #[serde(flatten)] attribute at line 27 allow attackers to inject fields from CommonCheckerConfig that might conflict with HardwareCheckerConfig fields? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Race condition] The async check() function at line 132 calls target_provider.provide().await at line 142. Can concurrent calls to check() create race conditions in the output_cache or provider state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [TOCTOU] Between the time SystemInformationProvider returns data at line 142 and when it's validated at lines 154-166, can the actual hardware change (hot-swap, container migration) creating a time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerability? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Cache invalidation] Does the SystemInformationProvider's cache (referenced in provider code) properly invalidate on hardware changes, or can stale metrics persist after hardware downgrades? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Struct: HardwareChecker] [Shared state] The HardwareChecker struct at line 51 stores config. If multiple threads access the same instance, can config be modified concurrently causing validation inconsistencies? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Provider timeout] If target_provider.provide() at line 142 hangs or times out, does the checker properly handle this to prevent validator startup deadlocks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Provider endpoint manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate the metrics_url used by SystemInformationProvider (from provider code) to point to a malicious server that provides fake hardware metrics? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [SSRF] Does the SystemInformationProvider perform proper URL validation, or can an attacker inject URLs that cause Server-Side Request Forgery when fetching system information? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [DNS rebinding] Can an attacker use DNS rebinding attacks against the SystemInformationProvider's metrics endpoint to fetch hardware information from internal networks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [TLS downgrade] Does the SystemInformationProvider enforce TLS for the /system_information endpoint, or can man-in-the-middle attackers downgrade to HTTP and inject false metrics? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/hardware.rs] [Function: check()] [Response injection] Can an attacker perform HTTP response splitting or injection attacks against the /system_information endpoint to provide malformed JSON that bypasses validation? (Medium)
